Thanks! This is a good plan for beginning implementation work. 

Some comments/questions interspersed below:
> 1.1 Administrative and Monitoring Overview
> 
> Administrative part of the interface should consist of three different 
> 'panels', one control and two configuration panels. The control panel 
> should consist of start, stop, pause, checkpoint, resume, and terminate 
> options. First configuration panel should be the crawl configuration panel 
> where the crawl is a web collection that will be harvest.  Second 
> configuration panel should be the crawler's configuration panel where the 
> crawler is a group of Heritrix configurable modules.
> Monitoring part of the interface should consist of Heritrix reports such 
> as progress and data captured, errors, and crawler status reports.
> This interface should also provide some basic authentication mechanism.

As with navigational headers on a website, some standard grouping
of status info and controls should appear on every page served by
the embedded webserver. For example...

   Crawling "_Fredonia2003_" [ _Pause_ | _More Options_ ]
   123,456 URIs collected [ _More stats_ ]
   Checkpoint #2: 98,765 URIs at 2003-10-01 03:45 

> 2. Administrative Panels
> 
> 2.1 Control Panel
> 
> The control panel should provide start, stop, checkpoint, pause, resume, 
> and terminate options. The operator should be able to use these options at 
> all times.

These names/descriptions could be further cleared up: 

> Start - starts the crawler.

Is this "start specifying a new crawl" or "begin crawling according
to an already-filled out specification"? 

> Stop - stops the crawler. When crawler is stopped with this option it can 
> be resumed from last checkpoint.
> 
> Pause (optional?)- stops crawling but not the crawler. This option will 
> pause (put to sleep) crawler's workers. Similar effect can be achieved by 
> checkpoint followed by stop options therefore pause option may be 
> redundant. 
> 
> Resume - resumes stopped/paused crawler. Stopped crawl is resumed from 
> last known checkpoint. Paused crawl is resumed by waking up paused 
> workers. 
>
> Checkpoint - it writes current crawler's state to a disk.
> 

Is there a way to freeze the crawler, change settings, and then 
unfreeze it without requiring a checkpoint? 

A state diagram showing how the UI options push a crawl through
its various states would be helpful, including the states before
the crawl is adequately configured to run (eg has no seeds, etc.).

> Terminate - it shutdowns the server and all crawl activities.

"Shutdown" might be a better name for this option, and a warning/
confirm should be required, as this option kills all OS processes
running the WUI and crawler.

> 2.2 Crawler Configuration Panel 
>  
> The crawler configuration panel should consist of Heritrix configurable 
> modules. Heritrix current modules are:
> -   selector
> -   scheduler
> -   store
> -   preprocessor
> -   DNS fetcher
> -   HTTP fetcher
> -   HTTP extractor
> -   HTML extractor
> -   MSDOC extractor
> -   SWF extractor
> -   PDF extractor
> -   archiver
> Default mode of the interface should hide this configuration panel. The 
> panel should be available in 'advance' mode. In this mode the operator 
> should be able to add, change or reconfigure any of these modules. The 
> operator should also be able to load any pre-existing XML 
> configuration file in both modes.

How do modules announce to the UI what sorts of configurable
options they offer? Should we use java "bean" conventions?

> 3. Monitoring and Progress Reports 
> 
> The monitoring part of the interface should provide the operator with 
> crawler's reports on progress and captured data, status, and 
> errors. 
> All statistics will be updated on demand by the operator or by 
> 'auto-refresh' option.

In addition to the other reports you listed, there needs to be
a way to perform the equivalent of a "tail" or "less" on key 
progress and error logs. 

> 4. Authentication Panel
> 
> The interface authentication should be a HTTP "Basic" or "Digest" 
> authentication. Only a single username/password is necessary for the 
> foreseeable future.
> This one username/password pair could be specified on the command-line. 
> All traffic of the interface should be logged.

This isn't really a panel; rather, attempts to use any portion of
the UI will trigger a login challenge if the user is not already 
logged in.

- Gordon
